Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Artificial Intelligence for Analysis Of Visual Art
Award.AbstractNarration:
This I-Corps project utilizes artificial intelligence (AI) principles to detect abnormalities in images - in particular, it focuses on ways to enable visual information extraction.

Large collections of art and other images exist in digitized form but there are few automated methods for processing and indexing this data. This project facilitates a wide range of applications from education to online markets because the technology focuses on automated analysis of art and other images based on algorithmic methodologies in artificial intelligence. For example, the project's computational models might facilitate indexing large-scale collections of art and extracting useful information from this massive visual data. In this context, knowledge can be useful to online and traditional galleries, collectors, educators, authenticators and others in making informed decision regarding artwork and artist.

While the AI techniques are applicable to a broad range of images, the I-Corps team initially developed prototype computational models for analyzing artworks based on the visual information extracted from paintings. The computational models enable the system to perform perceptual and cognition tasks on digitized art for classification of paintings. AI algorithm can be specialized or tuned and optimized for different domains of fine-art analysis. While initially focusing on customer discovery within artistic contexts, the technology has the potential to be applicable in many different contexts. The I-Corps experience will help the team to better understand the market scope.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University New Brunswick
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

Performance_Institution.Name: Rutgers, The State University of N.J.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This I-Corps project aimed at developing a business plan to commercialize the technology developed by the Entrepreneurial Lead and the Principle Investigator for automated analysis of art, based on algorithmic methodologies in artificial intelligence. Large collections of available digitized art dictate the need for automated methods for processing and indexing this data. This would facilitate wide range of application from education to online markets.

The I-Corps program was essential for us to understand the market and develop a business plan. We seized the I-Corps opportunity to reach out for potential customers and learn about their needs in both the short and long term. This helped us to shape our business plan according to the actual needs of the art market. This also helped us fine-tune our technologies towards the needs of customers in this area.

The I-crops cohorts were a great learning experience to the IL and the PI. We conducted over 100 customer interviews with art galleries in DC, NYC, Boston, San Francesco, and Miami. We documented all interviews in the I-corps provided interactive system. We worked closely with our mentor as well as the I-corps instructors to develop a business plan centered around art galleries needs. After considering the market needs we concluded that the technology is not yet at the level to answer its needs. 

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2016
Modified by: Ahmed M Elgammal
